Name: Placing a cap on the correlated color temperature of new and replacement streetlights.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to placing a cap on the correlated color temperature of new and replacement streetlights

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
This Introduction was Filed (End of Session)

Attachments.Name: Minutes of the Stated Meeting - December 7, 2022

Summary: This bill would require that any lamp installed as part of the lighting of streets, highways, parks, or any other public place have a correlated color temperature no higher than 3000 Kelvin. All new and replacement outdoor lamps would be required to meet this standard.
Text:
Be it enacted by the Council as follows: 
      Section 1.  Subchapter one of chapter one of title 19 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 19-159.6 to read as follows:
      �19-159.6. Limitation on correlated color temperature of streetlights. a. Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms have the following meanings:
      Correlated color temperature. The term "correlated color temperature" means the perceived color of the light emitted by a lamp, expressed in Kelvin (K) units.   
      Kelvin. The term "kelvin" means the unit of measurement used to characterize the color of light emitted by a lamp. 
      b. Any lamp to be used in the illumination of streets, highways, parks, or any other public place shall have a correlated color temperature no higher than 3000 Kelvin. All new and replacement outdoor lamps shall be installed in accordance with this section.   
      
      �2. This local law takes effect immediately.

\ul\fs24\'a719-159.6. Limitation on correlated color temperature of streetlights. a. Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms have the following meanings:\par
Correlated color temperature. The term \ldblquote correlated color temperature\rdblquote  means the perceived color of the light emitted by a lamp, expressed in Kelvin (K) units.   \par
Kelvin. The term \ldblquote kelvin\rdblquote  means the unit of measurement used to characterize the color of light emitted by a lamp. \par
b. Any lamp to be used in the illumination of streets, highways, parks, or any other public place shall have a correlated color temperature no higher than 3000 Kelvin. All new and replacement outdoor lamps shall be installed in accordance with this section.   \par
